Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Nanosystems Enabled Intelligent End-effectors for Nanorobotic Manipulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Functionalized end effectors are built from nanosystems to support intelligent nanorobotic manipulation. This is achieved using segment-nanostructure-based nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) and nonophotonic systems. Internal electron tunneling and optical coupling are used as the common base of these end effectors for achieving high resolution while keeping to nano scale. Specific problems investigated include (1) the internal electron tunneling and optical coupling between the segmented elements in a nanostructure such as carbon nanotube shells, peapod nanowires, head-to-head positioned nanotube tips and dimmer nanospheres, (2) the development of sub-nanometer position/displacement sensors, picoNewton force sensors, and attogram mass detectors using the segmented nanostructures, (3) integrating these sensors onto transmission electron microscope compatible chips, atomic force catilevers, and rolled up helical nanobelts, and (4) the application of these systems.

The project impacts the development of new nanotechnology for nanorobotics including theory and processes for actual construction of systems. This leads to new tools for manufacturing and other technology fields such as the electronics and microscopy industries. Optical nanoantennas have the potential to remarkably enhance energy adsorption for solar cells. Applications are found in single molecule manipulation in biology, material characterization and inter-molecule interactions in supramolecular chemistry. General applications include the potential application of intelligent nanosystems in health care. Broad outreach is achieved through lectures, workshops, courses and websites for K-12 students and teachers, as well as for the public who have an interest in this emerging field.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 1959, Richard Feynman proposed in his prophetic speech "There is plenty of room at the bottom": “What I want to talk about is the problem of manipulating and controlling things on a small scale…I am not afraid to consider the final question as to whether, ultimately—in the great future—we can arrange the atoms the way we want: the very atoms, all the way down!” This NSF CAREER Award contributes to the development of such abilities in the field of nanorobotics and nanosystems focusing on building functionalized end-effectors from nanosystems for intelligent nanorobotic manipulation. The objective is to integrate research and educational activities in this field to create functionalized end-effectors using segment-nanostructure-based nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) and nanophotonic systems.

 

Internal electron tunneling and optical coupling are proposed as the common base of these end-effectors for achieving high resolution while keeping nanometer sizes. The following specific problems have been tackled and solved: (i) Investigating internal electron tunneling and optical coupling between the segmented elements in a nanostructure such as nested carbon nanotube shells, stacked graphene, peapod nanowires, and dimmer nanospheres. (ii) Developing subnanometer position/displacement sensors, picoNewton force sensors, and attogram mass detectors using the segmented nanostructures, and prototyping these sensors using nanotube fountain pen and nanorobotic assembly inside a scanning/transmission electron microscope. (iii) Correlating the electro/optomechanical properties with their atomic morphology change, and realizing batch fabrication. (iv) Applying these systems as end-effectors for creating integrated nanorobotic systems.

 

The systematic understanding of the internal tunneling/coupling properties of intersegmented nanostructures from the theoretic and experimental perspectives has offered deep insights for nanoelectronics and nanophotonics. Nano end-effectors can serve as intelligent tools for nanomanipulation and nanofabrication, sensors for micro-/nanorobots, and wireless energy or signal transmission devices. The potential applications of intelligent nanorobotic systems for autonomous nanomedicine are attracting tremendous interests in enabling non-invasive surgery. New instruments based on mass transport at the nanometer scale will enable single molecule detection for biology using optical antennas and in situ characterization of individual nanostructures for material science using sliding probe methods, and intermolecular interaction investigation for supramolecular chemistry. Optical nanoantennas have the potential to remarkably enhance the energy adsorption for solar cells.

 

This award and its Research Experience for Undergraduates has supported the research for 1 PostDoc, 5 Ph.D. and 2 M.S. students, and 3 undergraduate students. Intellectual outcome from the project includes 13 journal articles, 16 international conference papers and invited/keynote/plenary talks, 6 book chapters, 2 Ph.D. thesis, and 1 M.S. thesis. One of the Ph.D. students, Zheng Fan, was honored with a Fitch-Beach Award for the best graduate student from the College of Engineering at Michigan State University. Three conference papers were selected as Best Conference Paper or Finalists for Best Student Papers.

 

Nanorobotics and nanosystems are attractive themes to stimulate the interests of K-12 students and underrepresented students in science and engineering. The PI has established a lecture series and interactive hands-on workshops series focusing on “Robotic Systems in the Small”. The new results and devices from this project have been integrated into MSU’s College of Engineering Recruitment and K-12 Outreach Office programs such as (1) Wireless Integrated MicroSystems (WIMS) for Teens summer residential program; (2) Women in Engineering (WIE) summer residential program; (3) Motorola funded Middle and High School Research Experiences, (4) High School Engineering Institute and High School Research Experience for Teachers (RET) Training program, and (5) NSF BEACON Center, and introduced to public audience (http://www.trynano.org/dong.html). Scaled up paper models and molecule models of the building blocks and nanosystems, images and videos of molecular dynamics simulations, and videos of nanorobotic manipulation experiments were presented in seminars. Experiments have been demonstrated to these audience in the lab focusing on nanorobotic manipulation of CNTs and intermolecular/surface forces. A kit of scaled up model of motorized helical robotic swimmers were developed and used in competitions for K-12 students.

 

Achieved results from this project have been integrated into newly developed graduate courses on “Nanofabrication and Nanosystems (ECE 802-604)” and “Nanorobotics and Manufacturing (ECE 802-606)” at Michigan State University. These courses expose students the most essential topics in the engineering at the nanometer scale. Carefully selected topics emphasize the most practical conventional and unconventional nanofabrication technologies. A variety of nanosystems has been introduced starting from the building blocks (nanotubes, nanowires, graphene, etc.) to the system integration and characterization. These systems include nanoelectronic systems, NEMS, nanofluidic systems, nanophotonic systems, bio-inspired nanosystems, and other nanosystems. Introductory parts have been delivered to undergraduate courses including “Computer Aided Manufacturing (ECE 415)” and “Control Systems (ECE 313)”. Seminars were given to Eta Kappa Nu students at Michigan State University, the Air Force Institute of Technology, The University of Toronto, The City University of Hong Kong, Nagoya University, and so on.
